abbreviations.usage_example: Rx: Tincture valerian aa tincture passionflower = equal parts of each
abbreviations.notes: Very common in compound formulas. Indicates equal proportions.

abbreviations.usage_example: q.s. ad 100 mL = add enough [solvent] to bring total volume to 100 mL
abbreviations.notes: One of the most important pharmacy abbreviations. Used when exact quantity depends on context.

abbreviations.usage_example: gtt iii = 3 drops
abbreviations.notes: Singular: gutta (gt). Plural: guttae (gtt). Imprecise unit; volume varies by dropper and liquid.

abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 30 gtt b.i.d. = Take 30 drops twice daily
Sig: 1 tsp t.i.d. = Take 1 teaspoon three times daily
abbreviations.notes: The most common dosing frequency for herbal tinctures.

abbreviations.usage_example: Tr. Echinacea = Tincture of Echinacea
abbreviations.notes: Also written as 'tinct.' Both are standard abbreviations for tincture.

abbreviations.usage_example: Tinct. Valerianae = Tincture of Valerian
abbreviations.notes: Longer form of 'tr.' Followed by the genitive (Latin possessive) form of the herb name.

abbreviations.meaning: write on label; directions to patient
abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 30 gtt t.i.d. in water = Label: Take 30 drops three times daily in water
abbreviations.notes: Introduces the patient instructions section of a prescription or formula.

abbreviations.usage_example: Rx: Tr. Echinacea ℥ii = Take: Tincture of Echinacea, 2 ounces
abbreviations.notes: From Latin 'recipe' (imperative: take). Opens a prescription or formula. The symbol ℞ is a stylized abbreviation with possible origins in the Eye of Horus or Jupiter symbol.

abbreviations.usage_example: Administer stat = Give immediately
abbreviations.notes: Used for single urgent doses. Rarely needed in herbal practice but appears in clinical settings.

abbreviations.meaning: as needed; as the situation arises
abbreviations.usage_example: 30 gtt p.r.n. for anxiety = 30 drops as needed for anxiety
abbreviations.notes: Very common in herbal dosing. Implies a maximum frequency should also be specified.

abbreviations.meaning: at bedtime (at the hour of sleep)
abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 60 gtt h.s. = Take 60 drops at bedtime
abbreviations.notes: Common for sedative and nervine formulas.

abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 1 tsp a.c. = Take 1 teaspoon before meals
abbreviations.notes: Important for bitters and digestive formulas which work best on an empty stomach.

abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 1 tsp p.c. = Take 1 teaspoon after meals
abbreviations.notes: Used for herbs that may cause gastric irritation on an empty stomach.

abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 20 gtt q.i.d. = Take 20 drops four times daily
Disp: caps No. xxx = Dispense 30 capsules
abbreviations.notes: Modern herbal practice uses '00' or '0' size vegetarian capsules most commonly.

abbreviations.usage_example: Pulv. Glycyrrhizae = Powder of Licorice
abbreviations.notes: Refers to finely ground herb material, suitable for capsule filling or direct use.

abbreviations.usage_example: Syr. Althaeae = Syrup of Marshmallow
abbreviations.notes: Herbal syrups use sugar or honey as the preservative base for aqueous extracts.

abbreviations.usage_example: Ung. Calendulae = Calendula Ointment
abbreviations.notes: Refers to semi-solid topical preparations. In herbal practice, typically oil-and-beeswax based.

abbreviations.usage_example: Sig: 10 gtt q.h. during acute phase = Take 10 drops every hour during acute phase
abbreviations.notes: Used in acute dosing protocols. Variations: q.2h. (every 2 hours), q.4h. (every 4 hours), q.6h. (every 6 hours).

abbreviations.usage_example: ℥ss = half an ounce; gr ss = half a grain
abbreviations.notes: Placed after the unit symbol. Written as a subscript or lowercase 'ss' in handwritten prescriptions.

abbreviations.usage_example: fl℥ = fluid ounce; flʒ = fluid dram
abbreviations.notes: Also written as 'fld'. Distinguishes liquid measures from weight measures of the same name.

abbreviations.usage_example: Fld. Ext. = Fluid Extract (1:1 concentration)
abbreviations.notes: Alternative form of 'fl'. 'Fluid extract' (fluidextractum) is a specific 1:1 preparation in pharmacopeial terminology.

abbreviations.usage_example: Lot. Calaminae = Calamine Lotion
abbreviations.notes: A liquid topical preparation, thinner than an ointment or cream.

abbreviations.usage_example: Inf. Chamomillae = Infusion of Chamomile
abbreviations.notes: An aqueous extract made by pouring hot water over herb material and steeping. Distinguished from decoction by method.

abbreviations.usage_example: Dec. Glycyrrhizae = Decoction of Licorice
abbreviations.notes: An aqueous extract made by simmering herb material in water. Used for roots, barks, and hard plant parts.

abbreviations.usage_example: Disp: ℥iv = Dispense 4 ounces
abbreviations.notes: Instruction to the pharmacist/herbalist indicating the quantity to provide to the patient.

roman_numeral_convention.description: Quantities written as lowercase Roman numerals after unit symbol
